I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  In  2011,  the  Government  of  the  Philippines,  through  the  Department  of  Labor  and 
Employment  (DOLE),  requested  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  assistance  to  improve 
employment facilitation systems. Interventions were envisaged to support policy development, 
regulatory reviews, capacity development at public employment services offices (PESOs), and 
design and implementation of a pilot project assisting the school-to-work transition for at-risk 
youths. At-risk youths are those who are out of school and not working, with at least some high-
school  education.  In  response,  ADB  conducted  consultation  missions  in  2011.  During  the 
November 2011 fact-finding mission, DOLE agreed on the proposed impact, outcome and 
outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference of 
the  technical  assistance  (TA)  as  described  in  the  approved  concept  paper.  Subsequent 
meetings with DOLE, the PESOs, employee groups,  youth employment groups, and labor 
organizations provided additional background information that confirmed the need for the TA. 
ADB conducted additional missions with DOLE and stakeholders to develop the project design. 
The TA is included in the country operations business plan, 2013–2015 for the Philippines.1 The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The Philippine Development Plan, 2011–2016 aims to create 1 million new jobs per year 
and to maintain the unemployment rate within a narrow range of 6.8%–7.2%. Central themes of 
the  economic  program include  improving  the  business  climate  and  infrastructure  to  attract 
investment and create jobs, and implementing programs to improve youth skills and address the 
mismatch of skills in the labor market.  
 
3.  While  higher  and  sustainable  economic  growth  is  necessary  to  create  more  jobs, 
structural and policy impediments to employment generation must also be addressed. An ADB 
study of youth labor market experience found that high-school graduates are at-risk youths who 
have the most difficulty integrating into the labor market.3 In particular, the transition from school 
to work for high-school graduates and dropouts is relatively slow. They may require up to 4 
years to find a wage job compared with 2 years for college graduates. Only 50.0% of high-
school graduates actually find wage employment, indicating many are excluded from productive 
employment. The report also shows that the returns to education for high-school graduates are 
relatively low―college graduates earn 80.0% more than high-school graduates.   
 
4.  Several  factors  contribute  to  the  slower  transition  to  the  workplace  for  high-school 
graduates. First, economic growth averaging 5.0% per annum has not been adequate to create 
enough decent wage jobs for the 1 million new labor market entrants each year (economic 
growth above 6.0% is needed). Second, the labor market has been undergoing a structural 
change with increased demand for skilled workers relative to unskilled and semi-skilled workers. 
This change has resulted in a widening skills mismatch in the labor market. This is exacerbated 
by the education system, which appears to not properly equip at-risk youths with the requisite 
technical and life skills for entry into the labor market. Third, ADB staff analysis shows that 
socioeconomic status also influences the transition, with the transition to the labor market for 
young persons most difficult if parents are working in the informal sector, indicating some 
impediments to socioeconomic mobility of children from less well-off families. Fourth, public

provisioning of employment services to help school graduates enter the labor market are in the 
early stages of development and not well targeted. While the country has more 1,400 PESOs, 
less than 100 are institutionalized within local government units (LGUs), i.e., permanent offices 
with staff and budget. Limited labor market information (LMI) is available to school graduates, 
and limited job search assistance programs are linked to vocational training and workplace 
experience for recent high-school graduates. Fifth, some labor regulations have dampened 
employment growth especially for the youth, such as restrictions on the length of probation 
periods (maximum of 6 months), employment arrangements, and relatively higher severance 
pay regulations. Minimum wages may have hurt employment opportunities for school dropouts.4 
 
5.  DOLE is concerned about the slow school-to-work transition of youths and the quality of 
employment opportunities for high-school graduates. Employers complain about the lack of 
workplace readiness and skills mismatch of many school graduates entering the workplace. 
Youths complain about the lack of LMI and the availability of public services for employment 
advice and career counseling. 
 
6.  The government is aware of these structural and policy constraints to youth employment 
creation. In 2011, DOLE endorsed the Philippine Labor and Employment Plan, 2011–2016. The 
plan focuses on improving worker employability through cost-effective interventions that provide 
market-based incentives for hiring new workers, job searches, skills development, and income 
security. It includes recommendations to (i) review and reform the Labor Code of the Philippines 
to better align it with recent developments in international labor policy and regulation with the 
aim of boosting employment; (ii) adopt market-based incentives for income security, especially 
during  periods  of  unemployment  or  employment  separation,  such  as  some  form  of 
unemployment  insurance;  (iii)  adopt  a  public–private  partnership  framework  for  developing 
youth employment programs; and (iv) create programs to mitigate labor market and income 
risks to vulnerable workers.  
 
7.  Aligned  with  the  Philippine  Labor  and  Employment  Plan  recommendation,  DOLE 
initiated a youth employment pilot project—MyFirstJob—a DOLE flagship project. Following 
successful models in Latin America, Canada, and Europe, MyFirstJob will provide employment 
assistance to help high-school graduates integrate into the workplace. Services will include 
career counseling and development of individual career plans and grants for vocational training 
linked to workplace experience with private sector employers. In mid-2013, it will be tested in 
the PESOs of four LGUs, targeting 1,600 youths, of which 50% will be female. If the pilot project 
is successful, it will be rolled out nationally. At the same time, DOLE will continue to advocate 
and  support  capacity  development  for  the  establishment  and  institutionalization  of  PESOs 
nationally. In line with promoting employment, DOLE has initiated a review of the labor code to 
achieve a balance between employment-friendly regulations and income security for workers.  
 
8.  DOLE  is  coordinating  development  partner  support  for  the  Philippine  Labor  and 
Employment  Plan,  including  ADB,  the  Government  of  Canada  (through  the  Canadian 
International Development Agency), and the International Labour Organization. Through this 
government-led coordination, ADB is assisting DOLE in implementing selected components of 
its plan with a programmatic approach and TA (including this proposed TA project).5 Under 
subprogram 1 of the Increasing Competitiveness for Inclusive Growth  Program (ICIG), the 
government set out the foundations for boosting employment through regulatory reform and

3 
strengthening  employment  facilitation  systems,  including  capacity  development  for 
institutionalizing PESOs.6 Subprogram 2 of ICIG sets out prior expected actions (or policy 
triggers) for supporting employment growth with the central focus on operationalizing reforms 
through pilot projects. These actions include implementation of a regulatory review of the labor 
code, capacity development for the institutionalized PESOs, and implementation of MyFirstJob 
in four LGUs (through the PESOs). Subprogram 2 is expected to be submitted to the ADB 
Board of Directors in 2014. The purpose of the proposed TA is to support operationalization of 
these key interventions of the Philippine Labor and Employment Plan.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The impact will be enhanced employability of at-risk youths. This will be measured by  
(i) youth wage employment increasing by 5.0% per annum over the long-term average rate of 
3.1% (1991–2008), (ii) job placement rate for youths using MyFirstJob services 20% higher than 
for a similar group not receiving MyFirstJob services, and (iii) job placement rate for MyFirstJob 
youths  in  jobs  offering  social  protection  benefits  20%  higher  than  for  a  similar  group  not 
receiving  MyFirstJob  services.  The  outcome  will  be  improved  PESO  capacity  to  provide 
employment services. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Strengthened capacity for labor policy analysis and formulation. The TA 
will strengthen the Institute for Labor Studies (ILS) and DOLE’s policy development capacity to 
review the labor code and conduct impact assessments of active labor market programs. Output 
1 will include (i) support for review and regulatory impact assessments (including stakeholder 
consultations) of selected elements of the labor code and regulations in coordination with other 
relevant bureaus of DOLE, (ii) support for development and management of the e-regulation 
website  to  disseminate  information  on  proposed  regulatory  reforms  and  stakeholder 
consultations; (iii) capacity development of DOLE staff for policy analysis, impact evaluation, 
and policy formulation with support from the international labor policy and regulatory expert and 
through short-term formal training in the Philippines and within Asia, and participation in regional 
and international conferences (policy development support will be built around the ILS research 
and policy development work plan for 2013–2016); (iv) capacity development of DOLE in policy 
framework development and labor market governance systems; (v) funding for field research of 
selected employment policy issues; (vi) funding to develop methodologies, field research for 
establishing baseline data and tracing program recipients, and complete impact evaluation of 
selected labor and employment programs; (vii) development of standards for mitigating risks 
and  options  for  active  labor  market  and/or  employment  facilitation  programs;  and  
(viii) development of protocols for an early employment recovery program.  
 
11.  Output 2: Implementation of the MyFirstJob pilot project. This output is designed to 
enhance  the  employability  of  at-risk  youths  to  improve  their  integration  into  productive 
employment. The medium-term objective will be to improve the capacity of DOLE and the 
Bureau of Local Employment to deliver LMI and employment services. This will be achieved by 
supporting the national LMI systems and the MyFirstJob pilot project, which aims to (i) improve

Approach  and  Policy-Based  Loan  for  Subprogram  1  to  the  Republic  of  the  Philippines  for  Increasing

4 
LMI available to youths by strengthening PESO capacity to offer timely, accurate information on 
job vacancies and needed skills, and assist with job searches; and (ii) provide youths with 
access to  technical  and  life  skills training  demanded  by  employers,  opportunities for  work 
experience with learning on-the-job, and mentoring and tools for improving job searches and 
their outcomes. Output 2 includes five main activities: 
 
(i)  Improve  PESO  access  to  LMI  and  its  use  by  counselors.  This  includes:  
(a) developing an action plan to strengthen LMI systems nationally, and equip 
PESOs with hardware and software needed to access national and local LMI and 
manage  job  vacancies;  (b) providing  training  for  counselors  in  labor  market 
analysis;  (c)  preparing  counseling  materials  and  handouts  using  LMI;  and 
(d) improving the quality of services offered by job counselors. 
(ii)  Develop client assessment instruments. This includes (a) training counselors in 
assessment and counseling techniques, mentoring, and job search methods; and 
(b) training PESO managers in modern public employment services. 
(iii)  Reduce the mismatch of skills with employer needs. This includes (a) providing 
assessment  and  counseling  services  to  youths  based  on  LMI,  (b)  providing 
training in life skills to enhance work attitudes and behavior, (c) conducting youth 
technical  training  linked  to  current  labor  market  demand  through  a  voucher 
system, and (d) offering on-the-job training.  
(iv)  Improve  the  approach  of  youths  for  job  searches.  This  includes  (a)  training 
youths in job search techniques, and (b) strengthening PESO support for youths 
searching for jobs. 
(v)  Develop a monitoring and evaluation framework to assess the impact of the pilot 
project on the labor market performance of participants. This includes completing 
a  tracer  study  of  labor  performance  of  participants  (treatment  group)  and 
nonparticipants (control group). Labor market performance measures will include 
employment placement rates, earnings, and potential for job displacement.  
 
12.  Four PESOs will be chosen for the MyFirstJob pilot project and 1,600 youths will receive 
employment services. Demand for the pilot project is expected to exceed the number of places 
available; participants will be chosen by lottery to ensure random selection. A control group will 
be created by lottery from those not admitted. The pilot project, using this random experimental 
design, will be implemented for 15 months, after which an impact evaluation will be carried out. 
The impact of MyFirstJob on participants’ job placement and performance will be assessed by 
comparing those receiving services with those who do not. The results of the evaluation will be 
used in deciding a national rollout of MyFirstJob.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $5,591,897, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Government of Canada and administered by ADB. 7 The Government of the Philippines will 
provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, and other in-kind 
contributions.  
                                                
7 CIDA grant of $ 5,500,000 Canadian dollars is equivalent to $ 5,591,897 using exchange rate as of 15 January 
2013.

5 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  DOLE will be the executing agency. It will provide office space with furniture and support 
services for the consultants; the TA will provide office computers and supplies. ADB will engage 
eight international consultants (total of 40 person-months) and three national consultants (42 
person-months),  on  an  individual  basis  through  individual  contract  services,  to  carry  out 
activities under output 1. ADB will also engage a firm to provide five international consultants 
(total of 53 person-months) and seven national consultants (total of  92 person-months) to 
implement activities under output 2. The firm will be engaged through quality- and cost-based 
selection with an 80:20 quality–cost ratio. ADB will recruit all individual consultants for output 1 
and the firm for output 2 in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with the 
Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Equipment required under this TA will be procured following the Procurement Guidelines (2010, 
as amended from time to time); the assets will be handed over to DOLE upon TA completion. 
ADB  will  provide  to  the firm  an  advance  payment facility  based  on the  cost  estimates of 
MyFirstJob pilot project activities.8 
 
15.  Two project implementation units (PIU) will be established at DOLE for each output. The 
first PIU will be established at ILS to oversee implementation of activities under output 1. The 
ILS PIU will be responsible for coordinating TA activities, reporting on progress, and monitoring 
activities. The TA will engage a national consultant (para 14) to support the ILS PIU. ADB may 
also delegate some portion of the administration of TA capacity development activities to the 
ILS. For this purpose, ADB will provide an advance payment facility based on the cost estimates 
of  activities  (footnote  8).  A  second  PIU  will  be  established  at  DOLE’s  Bureau  of  Local 
Employment to oversee the implementation of MyFirstJob under output 2. The PIU will be 
responsible  for  coordinating  output  2  activities,  taking  on  the  overall  administrative  and 
supervisory  tasks,  communicating  with  ADB,  annual  auditing,  progress  monitoring,  and 
providing administrative support.   
 
16.  The TA will be implemented from March 2013 to February 2017. Consultant deliverables 
are included in the terms of reference in Appendix 3. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
 
17.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  ADB  administering  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $5,591,897 to the Government of the Philippines to 
be financed on a grant basis by the Government of Canada for Employment Facilitation for 
Inclusive Growth.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will engage a team of international and national 
consultants on an individual basis through individual consulting services to carry out activities 
under output 1. ADB will engage one firm to carry out activities under output 2 following quality- 
and cost-based selection (80:20 quality–cost ratio), using simplified technical proposal.  
 
A.  Output 1: Strengthened Capacity for Labor Policy Analysis and Formulation. 
 
2.  Eight international consultants (total of 40 person-months) and three national consultants 
(42 person-months) will be engaged to provide consulting services on capacity development at 
the Institute for Labor Studies (ILS) and relevant bureaus of the Department of Labor and 
Employment (DOLE).  
 
3.  Labor policy expert (international, 12 person-months). The expert should have (i) at 
least a master’s degree in economics specializing in the economics of labor, (ii) at least 10 
years experience in research and policy advisory functions with governments in developed and 
developing economies, and (iii) advanced survey research and statistical skills. The expert will 
work closely with ILS staff. Tasks include the following: (i) develop training modules on labor 
and  employment  analysis  and  policy,  and  provide  training;  (ii)  work  with  staff  to  produce 
research and policy discussion papers on the labor market in the Philippines covering labor 
market experiences of difference demographic groups, employment policies, selected labor 
policy and regulations, skills development, and other issues aligned with the ILS work plan; (iii) 
provide policy advisory briefs as needed; (iv) help ILS and relevant DOLE staff with regulatory 
impact assessments (RIAs) for selected regulations under the DOLE RIA work plan; (v) support 
DOLE with review of the Labor Code of the Philippines under RIA program; and (v) and provide 
assistance to ILS staff as needed. The expert will report to the ILS executive director and the 
ADB project manager.  
 
4.  Labor  regulations  expert  (international,  12  person-months).  The  expert  should  
(i) have at least a master’s degree in economics specializing in labor policy and regulation,  
(ii) have at least 10 years professional experience working on labor regulations in developed 
and developing economies, and (iii) be familiar with RIAs on labor regulations. The expert will 
work closely with ILS and DOLE staff on the review of labor regulations. Tasks include the 
following:  (i)  design  and  develop  training  modules  on  international  practices  on  labor 
regulations,  and  provide  in-house  training;  (ii)  work  with  staff  and  review  selected  labor 
regulations  that  impact  hiring,  dismissals,  employment  creation,  job  security,  and  income 
security; and other regulations on certification of professionals; (iii) help DOLE staff review the 
Labor Code of the Philippines; and (iv) respond to other DOLE requests as needed. The expert 
will report to the ILS executive director and the ADB project manager. 
5.  Monitoring and evaluation methodologies expert (international, 3 person-months).
